captions.text: Hello! My name is Dagmar.
Welcome to my cab. My Pink Lady.
This is my Pink Lady.
As you can see, a lot of pink and white.
Pink bed. The backside is pink.
The bottom is a nice pink, too.
This is pink, too.
Pink. Pink. Pink colours. Pink.
Pink socks.

Me and my truck...
When I'm inside my truck, we are one.

My truck is my place
when I'm not at home.
I love this space.
Yes!

I have changed the Volvo logo,
as you can see.

Normally, it's with an arrow -
a man's thing.
But this one is special - lady.

It's a little bit cold,
so I'll put my heater on.
There's my fridge.
My coffee machine.
And here I keep some of my movies.

Here we have a special mirror for
the ladies who want to put on make-up.
Sometimes, I work on my computer.

And if I don't feel like it,
I close it and watch my DVD or my TV.
Volvo has thought about the ladies, too.

This is not a man's thing anymore.
Not only for men, but for ladies, too.
�

"because americans are taller' No they're not, the lady in the video is 
Dutch, quite noticeable when she says "Koffiezetapparaat" instead of 
Coffeemaker. The Dutch are amongst the tallest people in the world on 
average. Trucks just differ depending on the distance they have to cover, 
in the US there's more distance to cover between towns (in Australia as 
well) so more space on the truck is assigned as living space.

comments.author: Stefan Paduraru

comments.text:
I think what SepherStar is getting at is that US drivers are gone from home 
for weeks at a time, and therefore having extra room makes the truck more 
inviting (to an extent).Obviously length laws have a lot to do with 
Cabovers ruling EU roads;they were abolished in the US in the 70's (if my 
memory serves me) and since then Conventionals have taken over.I think 
cabovers are cool,and would have been useful when going to shippers that 
weren't built for 53' trailers.
comments.author: Bob Sharma

comments.text:
You're wrong. Most countries in EU do not allow long haul trucks to be 
longer than 18meters so in order to use space smarter 9for hauling) , cabs 
are shorter. I bet you've never drove a truck in Europe neither seen one in 
your life in person except YT. I did. Ankara to Graz and Basel on regular 
basis. My runs were short compared to other people who drove from port of 
Athens to Denmark,Lithuania or Latvia....
comments.author: Marjan C.

comments.text:
We have big cabs in the US because North American long haul truckers cover 
considerable more distance than most European truckers, and usually work in 
teams. The cabs must frequently accommodate living space for two people.
comments.author: SepherStar

comments.text: What great news for the rest of us!
comments.author: Sarkazmo Loafy

comments.text:
She is awesome, I love her! Hehehehe. She's very cool and has her own 
style. She gets the job done but does it her way. Love the spirit.
comments.author: Sarkazmo Loafy

comments.text:
Also, i forgot to mention that most countries in European union have a law 
that has a LIMIT for length of vehicle which is 18 meters, that's why the 
cab is flat - to use space as much as possible. "tiny" trucks but much 
stronger than any kenworth, freightliner, piterbilt or any other.
comments.author: Marjan C.

comments.text:
..and the quality is poor compared to original Swedish Volvo engines. Trust 
me dude, when you're all of your life around trucks, you learn a lot of 
things which you even think imagine you would.
comments.author: Marjan C.

comments.text:
For Volvo usa is cheaper to put Cummins inside than to import ORIGINAL 
Volvo engine from Sweden which is way more reliable. ONLY the Volvo emblem 
is similar to European truck, nothing else. For Usa truck is NOT more 
efficient, but different all around: Chasis is made in Mexico and assembled 
in States. 70% of Engine parts are made in Liuzhou (China) assembled in San 
Luis (Mexico) and finally shipped to Usa where engine block is made so the 
cummins engine can be called "made in usa".
comments.author: Marjan C.

comments.text:
so I don't understand why Volvo makes 2 types of trucks...ours (USA) and 
the euros...maybe ours is more efficient because it looks more aerodynamics 
?
comments.author: thevinceberry

comments.text: lol...from ( an american )
comments.author: thevinceberry

comments.text:
You're wrong dude.EU trucks are quieter more than you think. Easier to 
drive as well.Some of them are even semi-auto or full auto (push 
button).I've driven and still do american truck (2008 Kenworth W900L) and I 
can tell you there is less space in EU trucks, they're smaller compared to 
US but same HP or even more. Best example is Scania 730 (16.4 Liter/730hp) 
EU trucks I've tried: DAF, MAN, Mercedes, Scania & Renault.They are all 
awesome Noisiest eu truck is Kamaz but it can take most beating.
comments.author: Marjan C.

comments.text:
now that's cool truck and job also. Respect from Poland Dagmar....hope to 
customize that my car someday
comments.author: Kosstyan

comments.text:
Never driven a cab over, wouldn't mind it, only driven US style. Would 
imagine you cut that wheel pretty tight on turns, which is awesome, but 
could also imagine the engine noise and vibration, not only from the motor 
but the tire sitting directly under you.
comments.author: goaguilera

comments.text:
One of the other reasons of this COE choice is also due to the 
infrastructure and road quality in Europe. Highways in Europe are generally 
very good quality with good maintenance (done with high tolls taxes). So 
wheelbase is less important (and the all cabin's mounted on air-chocks 
system). There's perhaps also easier access to public showers around 
highways on gas stations (so less need to have one in a sleeper cab). 
Again, I just try to explain the reasons why there's some differences.
comments.author: Phil Smith

comments.text:
Of course, I agree with you. There's no _need_ for COE in the US due to the 
kind of road and length limitation in comparison to Europe. I'm not even 
saying one is better than the other one. I just explain that it completely 
makes sense in Europe to have COE. They've also done some good improvements 
and there's no need for two people to tilt the cabine. It could be done by 
one person only in less than a minute: /watch?v=flqlsxHrIuU That's the 
reason why, outside of the US, COE is used.
comments.author: Phil Smith

comments.text:
I never said the Europeans should drive American-type trucks, I was 
explaining why Americans don't drive European type trucks. Like I said, 
cab-overs make sense in Europe where the roads are tight and the overall 
length is limited. Since we don't have those problems, and since long-nose 
trucks have benefits of their own, there is no reason why we would drive 
cab-overs. And I know US truckers dislike having to have everything in the 
cab anchored, and needing two people to open the engine bay.
comments.author: justforever96

comments.text: Встречал её где то в европе на разгрузке
comments.author: Klaipeda7

comments.text:
Hallo Dagmar, allereerst vind ik het een mooie video van een prachtige en 
smaakvolle ingerichte cabine, en niet te vergeten jouw spontane commentaar 
erbij maakt het helemaal af. P.S. let niet te veel op zogenaamde 
muggenzifterige landgenoten die zich voor doen als engelstalige experts. Je 
moet maar denken: zolang je geen aanmerkingen krijgt van authentieke 
engelstaligen is er niets mis mee. Ik kon je in ieder geval goed volgen:) 
M.V.G. de zoon van een voormalig internationaal chauffeur.
comments.author: vimponex

comments.text:
Zeg ventje, ik heb eens voor het gemak wat reacties van je door zitten 
lezen, en helaas moet ik concluderen dat dat engels van jouw hand zeldzaam 
tenenkrommend slecht is. Dus laat ik je bij deze dus de tip geven, pas te 
reageren wanneer je je eigen engels wat bijgespijkerd hebt. Oke? Iets met 
splinter en balk, als je daar tenminste ooit van gehoord hebt.
comments.author: vimponex

comments.text:
I didn't knew cavemen had access to the Internet... Welcome to the modern 
world then ;)
comments.author: Phil Smith

comments.text:
Spend 6 days a week living night and day in your truck cabin, and you'll 
see if you don't want something more "fancy" (I'd say more "personal") than 
a regular factory cabin. After few months (or even years) you'd hate your 
job just like millions of people hate to work on cubicle offices. When 
you're a trucker, your cabin might become your "first" home. Make it fit to 
you and you'll be happy to do the job you love as long as you can.
comments.author: Phil Smith

comments.text:
You probably never been outside of the US and seen from your own eyes how 
tiny some roads could be anywhere else than North America (i.e. Europe) and 
I'm not even mentioning some crowed cities such London, Paris, etc... 
Having shorter cabin helps to stay under the overall length limit with the 
more space for goods and better mobility. You might not believe me, but if 
you travel you'll notice it often could look like that: watch?v=7-_m9XTsfd8 
Access to engine on a COE is easy from front & top.
comments.author: Phil Smith

comments.text:
wordt echt ziek van al die kut engels sprekende die maar over het accent 
lopen te zeiken spreken zelf geen een andere taal ,nederlanders moesten 
maar een wat minder engels proberen te praten blijft onze taal teminste 
schoon . verders dagmar mooi om te zien dat je het goed voor elkaar heb ,ik 
zelf rijd al een paar jaar in zuid amerika met een kenworth , het gaat je 
goed
comments.author: mechtilda koot

comments.text:
LOL, I love the female symbol behind the Volvo logo on the headrests, 
instead of the usual male symbol. But if a truck is meant to be a working 
machine meant to make money, I never understood why people would spend so 
much putting all kinds of stuff into it to make it fancy. I mean, how much 
does a totally pink interior cost you? Unless it attracts customer 
attention and makes you back what you paid, it doesn't make sense. But 
that's just as far as business goes; pleasure is important too!
comments.author: justforever96

comments.text:
You mean Europe is tiny compared to the size of its population compared to 
the amount of open space and distances in the US? That's a lot of the 
reason Americans like cab-back trucks, in addition to riding a lot better 
on rough roads with a long wheelbase and being much easier to get to the 
engine. The US limits the length of the TRAILER, not the overall length, so 
what benefit would a short cab have, unless you drive in the city a lot? 
Yes, he's an a-hole, but your reasons are dumb.
comments.author: justforever96

comments.text: I'm guessing that was supposed to be a joke?
comments.author: justforever96
